posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked:
It had occurred to me that my team does not do a good job with data.

There are tons of data we could be storing… Control Inputs, Motor Inputs, PDP Channel Information, What Mode we are in. If we timestamped each entry of this data type we could then analyze it later on.

Is there any existing functionality of something like this in the WPILIB or something open source? I couldn’t find anything in the docs. I can’t imagine I’m the first one that has thought of this. Just wanted to ask before I go and try and reinvent the wheel!

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Funny you should ask… I’m working on this right now and plan to include it in WPILib 2022 (although it might not make the kickoff release).

posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked: Darn! Any chance you could give a sneak preview of what you are working on? This is our last thing we hope to accomplish before kickoff so we don’t have to spend time on it during the season.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: I’ll put the current state up on GitHub tonight.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
Shuffleboard has the ability to record and playback and convert to csv.

Shuffleboard can log all widget updates during a session. Later the log file can be “played back” to see what happened during a match or a practice run. This is especially useful if something doesn...

posts.name: Jonah Bonner
posts.cooked:
This is definitely an exciting project, and I’m looking forward to following its future development. I’ll also throw my hat in the ring, since I’ve been up to my ears in logging recently. One of 6328’s key projects this offseason was developing our own Java logging framework. We’ll have much more information to share soon, but here are the key points:

The framework is built around the principle of logging all input data to the robot code such that a match can be replayed and examined in a simulator. It also records more traditional “output data” (like odometry) for easy access.

One of our goals was to support a high level of logging while minimizing changes to robot code. The framework exists on top of the command based structure (or similar), recording and replaying data in the background whenever possible.

All of the data is saved in a binary format and read by a custom viewer application (see below). It can also read live data from the robot over the network.

As part of 6328’s efforts with the openalliance , all of our code is open source and we’ll do our best to support other teams utilizing it.

We still have some final work to do before the framework is ready for competition use, but everything should be made available before kickoff.

advantage-scope 2500×1385 648 KB

advantage-scope 2500×1385 648 KB

advantage-scope 2500×1385 648 KB

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: Nice work!  It looks very similar to the overall thrust of my future development plans.  Once I finish implementing data logging, my next project will be an an application for offline data analysis (similar to Glass, and using the same GUI framework, but focused on non-real-time).
